title: Soundproof phone booths give BHP a line to the future
text:
About 45 sleek white soundproof ''phone booths'' are dotted throughout BHP's eight floors in a new $260 million office tower in Adelaide, solving the problem of allowing workers to make confidential calls and still get the benefits of working in an open-plan office.

BHP has also taken measures to ensure security of energy supply in the building in the wake of a bruising state-wide power blackout in 2016 in South Australia that crippled the company's Olympic Dam copper mine in the north of the state.

The mining group's high-tech Integrated Remote Operations Centre on Level 3 of the GPO Exchange has its own power supply that can keep operations running for at least 48 hours should the unthinkable happen and the state suffer another blackout.

The foyer of the $260 million GPO Exchange office tower in Adelaide, which is BHP's new headquarters in South Australia.

The new 20-storey office tower at 10 Franklin St in the Adelaide CBD is owned by Charter Hall's $6.5 billion Prime Office Fund and 1,500 people are in the final stages of shifting into their new home. BHP has naming rights and occupies floors three to 10, while the South Australian Attorney-General's Department has the upper floors of what was a former telephone exchange.

Simon Stockfeld, Charter Hall's regional development director, said a high-tech approach had been used throughout the building, with one eye on attracting the Millennial generation as the next wave of workers.
description: Charter Hall's new $260m office tower for BHP is high-tech and has an answer for one of the biggest problems in open-plan workplaces.
